page.title: Chronology of Provisional Irish Republican Army actions (2000–09)

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.2.7.1)
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2013}} {{Use British English|date=January 2013}} This is a '''chronology of activities by the Provisional Irish Republican Army''', an [[Irish republicanism|Irish republican]] [[paramilitary]] group from 2000 to 2009.
{{TOC right}}
==2000== *16 March 2000: an IRA engineer defused a bomb left outside the offices of [[dissident republican]] party [[Republican Sinn Féin]] on the Falls Road, Belfast.<ref>http://www.anphoblacht.com/contents/5976</ref> *April 2000: an IRA [[active service unit]] was intercepted by the [[Garda Síochána]] in Dublin and two members were arrested. The unit is believed to have been on its way to kill Dublin drug lord [[Martin Foley]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2000/0913/viper.html|title=RTÉ News: Foley interviewed by Gardaí following attempt on his life|publisher=RTÉ.ie|date=13 September 2000}}</ref> *30 April 2000: Drug dealer Thomas Byrne was shot dead in central Dublin, allegedly by the IRA.<ref>http://www.irishtimes.com/culture/drug-dealers-dicing-with-death-1.266722</ref><ref name="upto40">[http://www.independent.ie/opinion/analysis/up-to-40-gang-murders-still-unsolved-26228007.html "Up to 40 gang murders still unsolved" (reference to Thomas Byrne)], independent.ie; accessed 3 November 2015.</ref> *29 May 2000: Edmund McCoy died several hours after being shot at the Motte 'n' Bailey Bar, Kingsway, [[Dunmurry]], County Antrim. He was reportedly a suspected drug dealer. The [[Royal Ulster Constabulary]] blamed the IRA for the killing.<ref name=ch00>{{cite web|url=http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/sutton/chron/2000.html|title=CAIN: Sutton Index of Deaths|publisher=Cain.ulst.ac.uk|date=10 October 1999}}</ref> *29 September 2000: Patrick Quinn was shot dead in The Depot Bar, Union Street, [[Magherafelt]], County Londonderry. Quinn was reportedly a suspected drug dealer and was shot shortly after the IRA had ordered him to leave the area.<ref name=ch00/> *13 October 2000: [[Real IRA]] member Joseph O'Connor was shot dead while sitting in his car in the [[Ballymurphy, Belfast|Ballymurphy]] area of Belfast, during a republican dispute. The Provisional IRA is believed responsible.<ref name=ch00/>
==2001== *7 January 2001: the IRA was blamed for carrying out a punishment beating on a convicted criminal in Ballymurphy, Belfast.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2001/jan/07/northernireland.henrymcdonald|location=London, UK|work=The Guardian|first=Henry|last=McDonald|title=Sick mother speaks out over IRA beating of teenage son|date=7 January 2001}}</ref> *21 April 2001: Christopher O'Kane, reportedly a suspected drug dealer, was shot dead near his home, Milldale Crescent, Tullyally, Derry, by four gunmen. It is believed that the IRA was responsible.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/sutton/chron/2001.html|title=CAIN: Sutton Index of Deaths|publisher=Cain.ulst.ac.uk}}</ref> *14 July 2001: gangland figure Seamus "Shavo" Hogan is gunned down in [[Crumlin, Dublin]], reportedly by the IRA or a proxy.<ref name="upto40"/>
==2002== *8 September 2002: the IRA was blamed for carrying out a punishment beating on a South Armagh man.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/victims-of-punishment-beatings-only-14-years-old-503665.html|work=Irish Independent|first=Jim|last=Cusack|title=Victims of 'punishment' beatings only 14 years old|date=15 September 2002}}</ref> *11 October 2002: a five-man IRA unit was captured by Gardaí in [[Bray, County Wicklow]]. It is believed the unit, members of the Dublin Brigade, were on their way to carry out an armed hijacking. The men were in a small van dressed in Garda uniforms, and had stun-guns and [[CS gas]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2005/0221/ira.html|title=Ó Snodaigh baffled about election posters|publisher=RTÉ.ie|date=21 February 2005}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Birth of a Nation|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/sinn-feinira-agents-spied-on-mccreevy-486527.html|title=Sinn Féin-IRA agents spied on McCreevy|publisher=Independent.ie|date=28 November 2004}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Staff|url=http://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/special-branch-head-believes-men-were-in-ira-169990.html|title=Special Branch head 'believes men were in IRA'|publisher=Breakingnews.ie}}</ref>
==2003== *12 March 2003: Irish republican Keith Rogers was shot dead in Cullaville, South Armagh, during a shootout involving a number of feuding IRA members, according to police. The IRA claimed Rogers had been shot while confronting local criminals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/issues/violence/deaths2003draft.htm|title=CAIN: Issues: Violence - Draft List of Deaths Related to the Conflict in 2003|publisher=Cain.ulst.ac.uk}}</ref> *11 October 2003: The IRA were allegedly responsible for the kidnapping of a dissident republican, Brendan Rice, in [[Newcastle, County Down]]; Rice was later released.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/3184812.stm|title=Abducted man released|publisher=BBC News|date=12 October 2003|accessdate=8 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Staff|url=http://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/police-question-man-over-abduction-117096.html|title=Police question man over abduction|publisher=BreakingNews.ie|date=13 October 2003}}</ref>
==2004== *19 January 2004: A dissident republican who was shot in the ankles in a punishment shooting blamed the Provisional IRA for the attack. The man from west Belfast was a member of an organisation which provided support to the families of imprisoned Real IRA (RIRA) members .<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishfreedomcommittee.net/NEWS/january_2004.htm#provos_attack_campaigner|title=January 2004|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> *20 February 2004: The IRA were accused of being responsible for the kidnap and attempted murder of ex-[[Irish National Liberation Army]] (INLA) member Bobby Tohill. The van in which he was being transported was rammed by police and four men were arrested. The IRA stated that it had not authorised any action against the man in question. Tohill required 93 stitches following the ordeal and went into hiding.<ref>{{cite news|author=Staff|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/sinn-fein-warned-that-time-running-out-for-end-to-paramilitary-violence-186316.html|title=Sinn Féin warned that time running out for end to paramilitary violence|publisher=Independent.ie|date=26 February 2004}}</ref> *5 September 2004: The IRA is believed to have been responsible for a fire-bomb attack on a fuel depot in [[Belfast|South Belfast]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Staff|url=http://www.breakingnews.ie/2005/05/24/story203997.html|title=IRA still active|publisher=BreakingNews.ie|date=24 May 2005}}</ref>
==2005== *30 January 2005: [[Murder of Robert McCartney|Robert McCartney]] is stabbed to death in a fight with IRA members being involved. Initially Sinn Féin denied IRA involvement but later it suspended 7 Sinn Féin members who had been present and the IRA also cleared witnesses to co-operate with the police investigation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/7476244.stm|title=Spotlight on McCartney trial|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> McCartney's family claim they have been intimidated by the IRA.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/4551468.stm|title=McCartney 'killer plans US move'|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> *2 February 2005: The IRA issued a statement summarizing their ''"ambitious initiatives designed to develop or save the peace process"'', including three occasions in which they had complied with the [[Independent International Commission on Decommissioning]] in putting weapons beyond use. The statement went on to say, ''"At this time it appears that the two governments are intent on changing the basis of the peace process. They claim that 'the obstacle now to a lasting and durable settlement… is the continuing terrorist and criminal activity of the IRA'. We reject this. It also belies the fact that a possible agreement last December was squandered by both governments pandering to rejectionist unionism instead of upholding their own commitments and honouring their own obligations."'' The statement concluded with two points: ''"We are taking all our proposals off the table"'' and ''"It is our intention to closely monitor ongoing developments and to protect to the best of our ability the rights of republicans and our support base"''.<ref>{{cite news|title=IRA statement: 2 February 2005|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/4074652.stm|publisher=BBC|accessdate=8 October 2015}}</ref> *3 February 2005: Following statements from the British and Irish governments, claiming that the new IRA statement was no cause for alarm, the IRA issues a second two-sentence statement: ''"The two governments are trying to play down the importance of our statement because they are making a mess of the peace process. Do not underestimate the seriousness of the situation"''.<ref>{{cite news|title=Concern over new IRA warning|url=http://www.cnn.com/2005/WORLD/europe/02/04/nireland/index.html?eref=sitesearch|publisher=CNN|date=4 February 2005|accessdate=3 November 2015}}</ref> *10 February 2005: The [[Independent Monitoring Commission]] reported that it firmly supports the [[Police Service of Northern Ireland]] and [[Garda Síochána|Garda]] assessments that the PIRA was responsible for the [[Northern Bank robbery]] and recommends financial and political sanctions against [[Sinn Féin]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Fourth Report of the Independent Monitoring Commission |url=http://www.independentmonitoringcommission.org/documents/uploads/HC%20308.pdf |publisher=Independent Monitoring Commission |date=10 February 2005 |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070614121443/https://www.independentmonitoringcommission.org/documents/uploads/HC%20308.pdf |archivedate=14 June 2007 |df=dmy }}</ref> *6 April 2005: Sinn Féin leader [[Gerry Adams]] calls on the IRA to initiate consultations "as quickly as possible" to move from being a paramilitary organisation to one committed to purely non-military methods.<ref>{{cite news|title=Text of Adams speech in full|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/4417575.stm|accessdate=3 November 2015|publisher=BBC|date=6 April 2005}}</ref> *12 April 2005: A Dublin man, Joseph Rafferty, was shot and killed in a shotgun attack in [[Dublin]]. The IMC and the family of the deceased have claimed that the IRA were responsible. The IRA has denied any involvement.<ref>{{cite news|author=20 best...|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/imc-report-to-link-joseph-raffertys-murder-to-provos-110776.html|title=IMC report to link Joseph Rafferty's murder to Provos|publisher=Independent.ie|date=1 February 2006|accessdate=3 November 2015}}</ref> *May 2005: The IRA is believed to have been responsible for intimidating a family to leave their home in Belfast.<ref name="independentmonitoringcommission.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.independentmonitoringcommission.org/documents/uploads/7th%20%20IMC%20%20Report.pdf|title=318283_HC546_7th Report|accessdate=8 October 2015|format=PDF}}</ref> *24 May 2005: The [[Independent Monitoring Commission]] claimed the IRA were still recruiting and training new members, and it was still involved in paramilitary and criminal activity.<ref>{{cite news|title=IRA still recruiting and robbing banks, says commission|author=David McKittrick|url=http://news.independent.co.uk/uk/ulster/article223066.ece|publisher=The Independent|date=25 May 2005|location=London, UK|accessdate=3 November 2015}}</ref> *July 2005: The IMC blamed the IRA for a punishment shooting of an alleged criminal in early July.<ref name="independentmonitoringcommission.org"/> *28 July 2005: The IRA release a statement that it is ending its armed campaign and will verifiably put its arms beyond use.<ref>{{cite news|title=Full text: IRA statement|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/Northern_Ireland/Story/0,,1537996,00.html|publisher=The Guardian|date=28 July 2005|location=London, UK|accessdate=3 November 2015}}</ref> *26 September 2005: International weapons inspectors issue a statement confirming the full decommissioning of the IRA's weaponry.<ref>{{cite news|title=IRA 'has destroyed all its arms'|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/4283444.stm|publisher=BBC|date=26 September 2005}}</ref>
==2006== [[File:PIRAcolourpartyDublin.JPG|thumb|right|IRA Colour Party in Dublin - 2009]] *1 February 2006: International weapons inspectors believe that not all arms were decommissioned on the day the IRA decommissioned. Claims began to circulate that the IRA held onto handguns and various other weapons.<ref>{{cite news|title=IRA 'still involved in crime'|author=Mark Oliver|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/Northern_Ireland/Story/0,,1699736,00.html|publisher=The Guardian|date=1 February 2006|location=London, UK}}</ref> *10 March 2006: The IMC claimed that members of the IRA were responsible for the hijacking of a lorry containing a consignment of spirits in [[County Meath]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.independentmonitoringcommission.org/documents/uploads/ACFEF3.pdf|title=IMC claims IRA responsible for lorry hijacking in Meath|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref>
==2008== *31 July 2008: The [[32 County Sovereignty Movement]] (often considered the political arm of the [[Real IRA]]), accused the IRA of assaulting one of their members in Derry, leaving the man with serious head and facial injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G1-182228078.html|title=Dissidents blame 'Provo gang' for weekend assault per ''Derry Journal''|date=1 August 2008|publisher=Encyclopedia.com|accessdate=8 October 2015}}</ref>
==2010== *9 February 2010: A representative of the IRA using the [[pseudonym]] "P. O'Neill" issued a statement confirming that [[Joe Lynskey|Joseph Lynskey]] of [[Belfast]] had been "executed" by the organisation in 1972. The statement said that the man had been an IRA member and was ''"court-martialled for breaches of IRA standing orders"'' and ''"was subsequently executed and buried in an unmarked grave."'' The statement went on to say that Lynskey had an affair with the wife of a Belfast republican and had ordered another IRA member to shoot the man. The IRA said it had not identified Lynskey's grave.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/forty-years-later-ira-finally-admits-to-manrsquos-lsquoexecutionrsquo-14673172.html|title=Forty years later, IRA finally admits to Belfast man's 'execution'|publisher=Belfasttelegraph.co.uk|accessdate=3 November 2015}}</ref> *March 2010: [[Social Democratic and Labour Party]] (SDLP) MLA for Newry & Armagh, [[Dominic Bradley]], claimed the IRA were responsible for a recent punishment shooting in the town of Meigh and an armed robbery in Armagh during which shots were fired.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sdlp.ie/ga/index.php/newsroom_media/newsarticle/bradley_provo_warlords_have_not_gone_away|title=Provos Warlords Have Not Gone Away|date=30 March 2010|publisher=Sdlp.ie}}</ref> *August 2010: The [[32 County Sovereignty Movement]], the Republican Network for Unity and the [[UPRG]], claimed that the IRA were responsible for a shooting incident in Gobnascale, County Londonderry. It is claimed that up to 20 masked men, some armed with handguns, attacked a group of teenagers who were engaging in anti-social behaviour at an [[interface area]]. A number of the teenagers were attacked and shots were fired into the air. The men are then reported to have removed their masks when the PSNI arrived and were subsequently identified as members of the Republican Movement. Sinn Féin denied the IRA were involved.<ref>[http://www.londonderrysentinel.co.uk/news/Were-Provos-behind-shooting-incident.6558729.jp "Were Provos behind shooting incident in Gobnascale?"], LondonderrySentinel.co.uk; accessed 8 October 2015.</ref><ref>[http://www.londonderrysentinel.co.uk/news/39Mainstream39-republicans-blamed-for-Gobnascale.6467389.jpMainstream Republicans blamed for Gobnascale incident], londonderrysentinel.co.uk; accessed 8 October 2015.</ref><ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00tbxvj The Nolan Show Radio Foyle], bbc.co.uk, 9 August 2010.</ref>
==2011== *20 June 2011: [[Jim Wilson (UK politician)|Jim Wilson]] and other Unionist leaders claimed the Provisional IRA was responsible for shooting two loyalist rioters in the legs during a UVF-led attack on the nationalist [[Short Strand]] area of Belfast. [[Alex Maskey]] denied the IRA was responsible for the shootings.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/console/b011y771|title=The Nolan Show, BBC Ulster|date=21 June 2011|work=BBC|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> *2 July 2011: An alleged member of the Provisional IRA was arrested for questioning over the stabbing of a man suspected of being linked to dissident republicans in the Markets area of Belfast.<ref>[http://www.independent.ie/national-news/in-brief-ira-suspect-in-mccartney-killing-arrested-after-stabbing-at-weekend-2811977.html IRA suspect in McCartney killing arrested after stabbing at weekend], independent.ie; accessed 8 October 2015.</ref><ref>[http://www.nuzhound.com/articles/breen/arts2011/jul11_Joe_Henry_family__SBreen_Daily-Mirror.php "Sisters claim McCartney killer stabbed their brother"], nuzhound.com; accessed 8 October 2015.</ref>
==2012== *16 August 2012: Three men and two women were charged with Provisional IRA membership in Belfast.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsletter.co.uk/news/ni-news/co-tyrone/legal-ban-on-naming-of-ira-accused-1-4166696|title=Legal ban on naming of IRA accused|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref>
==2013== *14 February 2013: [[Shankill Road bombing|Seán Kelly, the surviving Shankill Road bomber]], was arrested over a punishment shooting of an 18-year-old man in Belfast.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsletter.co.uk/news/headlines/tensions-mount-as-ira-bomber-released-over-shooting-1-4789880|title=Tensions mount as IRA bomber released over shooting|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> Kelly was later released unconditionally. [[Jim Allister]] of the [[Traditional Unionist Voice|TUV]] suggested the IRA was involved in the shooting<ref>[http://www.tuv.org.uk/press-releases/view/1758/sean-kelly-arrest---psni,-secretary-of-state,-sinn-fein-and-first-minister-challenged Allister claims PIRA involved in shooting of 18 year old man in Belfast], tuv.org.uk; accessed 8 October 2015.</ref> while the [[Ulster Unionist Party]] claimed the PSNI had come under pressure to distance mainstream republicans from the attack.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uup.org/news/1543/Elliott-concerned-at-Kelly-link-to-Ardoyne-shooting#.UTVRrWccDVw|title=Latest News|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> *1 March 2013: Seán Hughes, a suspected member of the [[IRA Army Council]], was charged {{Where|date=October 2015}} with IRA membership, speaking at a meeting and encouraging support for an illegal organisation.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-21621583|work=BBC News|title=Seán Hughes, 51, bailed over PIRA membership|date=1 March 2013}}</ref> *26 August 2013: It was alleged that the PIRA were responsible for planting two mortars along the border in [[County Armagh|South Armagh]]. Gardaí claimed the primed devices were intended as a warning by the IRA to the PSNI to cease disrupting the Provisional IRA's smuggling and diesel laundering businesses along the border.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/provisional-ira-behind-mortar-warning-to-psni-29542402.html|work=Irish Independent|title=Provisional IRA behind mortar warning to PSNI|date=1 September 2013}}</ref>
==2015== * 12 August 2015: Police believe members of the PIRA were involved in the fatal shooting of former IRA volunteer Kevin McGuigan in East Belfast. The shooting appears to be a revenge killing for the murder of another republican veteran in Belfast four months earlier.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-northern-ireland-34009501|work=BBC News|title=Kevin McGuigan murder: Police link Provisional IRA to killing in Belfast|date=20 August 2015}}</ref>
==See also== {{Commons category|Northern Ireland Troubles}} *[[Timeline of Continuity Irish Republican Army actions]] *[[Timeline of Real Irish Republican Army actions]] *[[Timeline of Irish National Liberation Army actions]] *[[Timeline of Ulster Volunteer Force actions]] *[[Timeline of Ulster Defence Association actions]] *[[Timeline of Ulster Defence Regiment operations]] *[[Timeline of the Northern Ireland Troubles]]
==Notes== {{reflist|2}} {{PIRA}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Chronology of Provisional Irish Republican Army actions (2000-10)}} [[Category:Chronology of Provisional Irish Republican Army actions]] [[Category:The Troubles (Northern Ireland)]] [[Category:Terrorist incidents in the 2000s]]
